articles.headline: A Stress Test for the Latest Bailout Plan
articles.snippet: Timothy Geithner’s bailout plan includes a so-called stress test to figure out how crippled big banks would be under various economic assumptions.
articles.abstract: Timothy Geithner’s bailout plan includes a so-called stress test to figure out how crippled big banks would be under various economic assumptions.
articles.lead_paragraph: First of all, let’s give the guy a break.

articles.headline: Legacy of a Crisis: A Generation Shy of Risk
articles.snippet: Young investors caught in the financial downturn still have time on their side.
articles.abstract: Young investors caught in the financial downturn still have time on their side.
articles.lead_paragraph: You did what you were supposed to do. College. Graduate school, maybe. Bought a home. Invested in mutual funds.

articles.headline: Failed Banks Pose Test for Regulators
articles.snippet: The F.D.I.C. faces tough choices as it struggles to manage $15 billion worth of loans and property from failed banks.
articles.abstract: The F.D.I.C. faces tough choices as it struggles to manage $15 billion worth of loans and property from failed banks.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  When regulators took over the First National Bank of Nevada last year, they faced a showdown with the Terrible Herbst, the mustachioed cowboy who boasts of being the “best bad man in the West.”

articles.headline: A New Role for Iraqi Militants: Patrons of the Arts
articles.snippet: A Baghdad exhibition organized by an aide of the cleric Moktada al-Sadr displays works of art by 39 Iraqi artists.
articles.abstract: A Baghdad exhibition organized by an aide of the cleric Moktada al-Sadr displays works of art by 39 Iraqi artists.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD  Two years ago the American authorities arrested Sheik Mazin al-Saedi, a senior aide to the anti-American cleric Moktada al-Sadr, accusing him of organizing kidnappings and killings.

articles.headline: Stimulus Plan Places New Limits on Wall St. Bonuses
articles.snippet: A provision buried in the stimulus bill passed by Congress would impose restrictions on executive bonuses at companies reaping bailout money.
articles.abstract: A provision buried in the stimulus bill passed by Congress would impose restrictions on executive bonuses at companies reaping bailout money.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  A provision buried deep inside the $787 billion economic stimulus bill would impose restrictions on executive bonuses at financial institutions that are much tougher than those proposed 10 days ago by the Treasury Department.
articles.byline: By Edmund L. Andrews and Eric Dash

articles.headline: Rainy Days in Paradise
articles.snippet: Luxury shared-home clubs are struggling in the economic downturn and many have filed for bankruptcy.
articles.abstract: Luxury shared-home clubs are struggling in the economic downturn and many have filed for bankruptcy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Destination clubs came into their own five years ago, as a growing number of affluent travelers sought all the advantages of a fancy second home without the inconvenience of upkeep or the monotony of going back to the same place year after year.

articles.headline: Stimulus Bill Would Bestow New Aid to Many Workers
articles.snippet: Many part-time, low-income and female workers who have lost their jobs stand to benefit from the federal stimulus bill.
articles.abstract: Many part-time, low-income and female workers who have lost their jobs stand to benefit from the federal stimulus bill.
articles.lead_paragraph: Many part-time, low-income and female workers who have lost their jobs stand to benefit from the federal stimulus bill.

articles.headline: For Fine Recession Wear, $7,000 Suits From Saks
articles.snippet: Saks Fifth Avenue is about to find out if there’s a market in the midst of a recession for $7,000 off-the-rack suits.
articles.abstract: Saks Fifth Avenue is about to find out if there’s a market in the midst of a recession for $7,000 off-the-rack suits.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, executives of Saks Fifth Avenue have been wooing one of the world’s most exclusive men’s wear lines.

articles.headline: Bipartisanship Isn’t So Easy, Obama Sees
articles.snippet: The party-line schism in the vote for the stimulus bill highlighted the difficulty of changing Washington’s ways.
articles.abstract: The party-line schism in the vote for the stimulus bill highlighted the difficulty of changing Washington’s ways.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  On the day before the big vote, President Obama took a freshman Republican member of Congress aboard Air Force One to visit Illinois. Before an audience in Representative Aaron Schock’s district, Mr. Obama praised him as “a very talented young man” and expressed “great confidence in him to do the right thing for the people of Peoria.”

articles.headline: Burris Now Says He Was Asked to Donate
articles.snippet: Senator Roland W. Burris of Illinois said he was asked for donations by former Gov. Rod Blagojevich’s brother.
articles.abstract: Senator Roland W. Burris of Illinois said he was asked for donations by former Gov. Rod Blagojevich’s brother.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO  Senator Roland W. Burris of Illinois acknowledged in documents made public Saturday that the brother of former Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich sought campaign fund-raising help from him in the weeks and months before his appointment to succeed Barack Obama as the state’s junior senator.

articles.headline: Job Losses Pose a Threat to Stability Worldwide
articles.snippet: High unemployment rates have led to protests in countries as varied as Latvia, Chile, Greece and Iceland and to strikes in Britain and France.
articles.abstract: High unemployment rates have led to protests in countries as varied as Latvia, Chile, Greece and Iceland and to strikes in Britain and France.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — From lawyers in Paris to factory workers in China and bodyguards in Colombia, the ranks of the jobless are swelling rapidly across the globe.

articles.headline: Taking the Wheel as Toyota Skids
articles.snippet: Akio Toyoda will take charge of the car company facing its most serious setback since a crisis in the early 1950s.
articles.abstract: Akio Toyoda will take charge of the car company facing its most serious setback since a crisis in the early 1950s.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT

articles.headline: The Worst Misstep: Geithner Added to the Doubt
articles.snippet: The plan unveiled by Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner was vague because vague is less scary, but investors have lost their patience with vague.
articles.abstract: The plan unveiled by Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner was vague because vague is less scary, but investors have lost their patience with vague.
articles.lead_paragraph: TIMOTHY GEITHNER, the brand new Treasury secretary, was panned last week for how he unveiled the Obama administration’s plan to rescue the financial system from the bankers who broke it.

articles.headline: Is America Ready to Quit Coal?
articles.snippet: With regulations to address climate change looming, coal power looks increasingly expensive.
articles.abstract: With regulations to address climate change looming, coal power looks increasingly expensive.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last May, protesters took over James E. Rogers’s front lawn in Charlotte, N.C., unfurling banners declaring “No new coal” and erecting a makeshift “green power plant”  which, they said in a press release, was fueled by “the previously unexplored energy source known as hot air, which has been found in large concentrations” at his home.

articles.headline: Inquiry on Graft in Iraq Focuses on U.S. Officers
articles.snippet: Authorities are investigating senior military officers over corruption allegations in the effort to rebuild Iraq.
articles.abstract: Authorities are investigating senior military officers over corruption allegations in the effort to rebuild Iraq.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal authorities examining the early, chaotic days of the $125 billion American-led effort to rebuild Iraq have significantly broadened their inquiry to include senior American military officers who oversaw the program, according to interviews with senior government officials and court documents.
articles.byline: By JAMES GLANZ, C.J. CHIVERS and WILLIAM K. RASHBAUM

articles.headline: U.S. Military Will Offer Path to Citizenship
articles.snippet: A new effort gives immigrants on temporary visas a chance to become citizens in as little as six months.
articles.abstract: A new effort gives immigrants on temporary visas a chance to become citizens in as little as six months.
articles.lead_paragraph: Stretched thin in Afghanistan and Iraq, the American military will begin recruiting skilled immigrants who are living in this country with temporary visas, offering them the chance to become United States citizens in as little as six months.

articles.headline: In Gingrich Mold, a New Voice for Solid Republican Resistance
articles.snippet: Eric Cantor, the House minority whip, is as responsible as anyone for the tough party line taken in the standoff with President Obama over the stimulus bill.
articles.abstract: Eric Cantor, the House minority whip, is as responsible as anyone for the tough party line taken in the standoff with President Obama over the stimulus bill.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The last time Congressional Republicans were this out of power, they turned to a college professor from Georgia, Newt Gingrich, to lead the opposition, first against President Bill Clinton in a budget battle in 1993, and then back into the majority the following year.

articles.headline: Chávez Decisively Wins Bid to End Term Limits
articles.snippet: President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela handily won a referendum that will allow him to run for re-election indefinitely.
articles.abstract: President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela handily won a referendum that will allow him to run for re-election indefinitely.
articles.lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela  President Hugo Chávez handily won a referendum on Sunday that will end presidential term limits, allowing him to run for re-election indefinitely and injecting fresh vibrancy into his socialist-inspired revolution.

articles.headline: This Just In: The Market Is Still Dead
articles.snippet: Financial journalists still can’t figure out how to cover the recession.
articles.abstract: Financial journalists still can’t figure out how to cover the recession.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last Monday on “Power Lunch” on CNBC, there was a segment that many people noticed and passed around the Web. Under the rubric “Turning the Corner,” Bill Griffeth and some of his colleagues were interviewing Nouriel Roubini, a professor of economics at the Stern School of Business at New York University, and Nassim Taleb, a derivatives trader, author and theorist about randomness.

articles.headline: Industry Makes Pitch That Smartphones Belong in Classroom
articles.snippet: Proponents of the sale of cellphones to schools say they are making the same kind of pitch the computer industry has been profitably making since the 1980s.
articles.abstract: Proponents of the sale of cellphones to schools say they are making the same kind of pitch the computer industry has been profitably making since the 1980s.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  The cellphone industry has a suggestion for improving the math skills of American students: spend more time on cellphones in the classroom.
articles.byline: By Matt Richtel and Brad Stone

articles.headline: What Convergence? TV’s Hesitant March to the Net
articles.snippet: While there is movement by chip makers to spur a new generation of TVs with full browser capability, TV manufacturers simply do not seem to want it.
articles.abstract: While there is movement by chip makers to spur a new generation of TVs with full browser capability, TV manufacturers simply do not seem to want it.
articles.lead_paragraph: PALO ALTO, Calif.  You would be hard-pressed to find a screen today that does not have Internet access. It’s not just the PC and the phone  online content appears in elevators, in the back of taxis and at your airplane seat. Some companies have even tried (albeit unsuccessfully) to get the Internet displayed on a refrigerator door.

articles.headline: Carlos Slim Helú: The Reticent Media Baron
articles.snippet: Mr. Slim, Mexico’s richest man and now a major shareholder in and lender to The New York Times, has a complex relationship with the news media.
articles.abstract: Mr. Slim, Mexico’s richest man and now a major shareholder in and lender to The New York Times, has a complex relationship with the news media.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY  Carlos Slim Helú was clearly annoyed. He had invited dozens of foreign correspondents to lunch one day last fall and, after many questions about business trends, one journalist pressed him on how it felt to be worth so much in a country in which many people struggle to get by.

articles.headline: Japan’s Economy Plunges at Fastest Pace Since ’74
articles.snippet: The country’s real gross domestic product shrank at an annual rate of 12.7 percent in the fourth quarter.
articles.abstract: The country’s real gross domestic product shrank at an annual rate of 12.7 percent in the fourth quarter.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO  Japan’s economy, the world’s second largest, is deteriorating at its worst pace since the oil crisis of the 1970s, hurt by shrinking exports and anemic spending at home.

articles.headline: Day Laborers Are Easy Prey in New Orleans
articles.snippet: Hispanic laborers, known for carrying large amounts of cash, are now New Orleans muggers’ prey of choice.
articles.abstract: Hispanic laborers, known for carrying large amounts of cash, are now New Orleans muggers’ prey of choice.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS  They are the men still rebuilding New Orleans more than three years after Hurricane Katrina, the head-down laborers from Honduras, Mexico and Guatemala who work on the blazing hot roofs and inside the fetid homes for a wad of cash at the end of the day.

articles.headline: Obama Is Said to Drop Plan for ‘Car Czar’ to Fix Detroit
articles.snippet: The administration will put the task of revamping G.M. and Chrysler in the hands of a presidential panel led by Timothy F. Geithner and Lawrence H. Summers.
articles.abstract: The administration will put the task of revamping G.M. and Chrysler in the hands of a presidential panel led by Timothy F. Geithner and Lawrence H. Summers.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  President Obama has dropped the idea of appointing a single, powerful “car czar” to oversee the revamping of General Motors and Chrysler and will instead keep the politically delicate task in the hands of his most senior economic advisers, a top administration official said Sunday night.

articles.headline: States and Cities Angle for Stimulus Cash
articles.snippet: Local officials facing budget deficits are jockeying for the upper hand in deciding how money from the federal stimulus package will be spent in their regions.
articles.abstract: Local officials facing budget deficits are jockeying for the upper hand in deciding how money from the federal stimulus package will be spent in their regions.
articles.lead_paragraph: Well before President Obama’s stimulus package completed its tortuous path through Congress last week, state and local officials facing multimillion-dollar budget deficits, crumbling infrastructure and the prospect of massive reductions in services were already jockeying for the upper hand in deciding how the money should be spent.

articles.headline: Pakistan Makes a Taliban Truce, Creating a Haven
articles.snippet: Critics called the accord a capitulation by a government desperate to stop months of fighting in Swat.
articles.abstract: Critics called the accord a capitulation by a government desperate to stop months of fighting in Swat.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The government announced Monday that it would accept a system of Islamic law in the Swat valley and agreed to a truce, effectively conceding the area as a Taliban sanctuary and suspending a faltering effort by the army to crush the insurgents.
